articles.headline: Could the Lone Fed Dissenter Be in Line for a Powerful Role if Trump Wins?
articles.snippet: Michelle Bowman, a Trump-appointed Fed official recently cited by JD Vance, has been gaining prominence.
articles.abstract: Michelle Bowman, a Trump-appointed Fed official recently cited by JD Vance, has been gaining prominence.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Senator JD Vance wanted to back up the assertion he made during the vice-presidential debate that new immigrants are exacerbating America’s housing affordability crisis, he cited a Federal Reserve study. Except it wasn’t a study. It was a speech by Michelle Bowman, a Fed governor appointed by former President Donald J. Trump.

articles.headline: U.S. Warns Israel of Military Aid Cut if Gazans Don’t Get More Supplies
articles.snippet: The demand from Israel’s closest ally came amid reports that the humanitarian catastrophe in the Gaza Strip has grown still worse in recent weeks.
articles.abstract: The demand from Israel’s closest ally came amid reports that the humanitarian catastrophe in the Gaza Strip has grown still worse in recent weeks.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States has warned Israel to increase the flow of humanitarian supplies into the war-devastated Gaza Strip within the next 30 days or risk losing military aid, American officials said Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Michael Crowley, Patrick Kingsley, Ronen Bergman and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: Meet the Election Denier Forecasting the 2024 Race
articles.snippet: Seth Keshel has become a darling among election deniers by factoring widespread voter fraud — the existence of which has been widely debunked — into his election predictions.
articles.abstract: Seth Keshel has become a darling among election deniers by factoring widespread voter fraud — the existence of which has been widely debunked — into his election predictions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Election forecasters think this year’s presidential race is too close to call. Nevada? A complete tossup. Pennsylvania? Anybody’s guess.

articles.headline: Washington Post C.E.O. Elevates Deal-Making to a Top Priority
articles.snippet: Will Lewis has said he has a mandate from the paper’s owner, Jeff Bezos, to grow the business, including through acquisitions.
articles.abstract: Will Lewis has said he has a mandate from the paper’s owner, Jeff Bezos, to grow the business, including through acquisitions.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the last several years, The Washington Post has sat out the deal fervor that has swept through much of the media industry.

articles.headline: Trump Escalates Threats to Political Opponents He Deems the ‘Enemy’
articles.snippet: Never before has a presidential nominee openly suggested turning the military on Americans simply because they oppose his candidacy. With voting underway, Donald Trump has turned to dark vows of retribution.
articles.abstract: Never before has a presidential nominee openly suggested turning the military on Americans simply because they oppose his candidacy. With voting underway, Donald Trump has turned to dark vows of retribution.
articles.lead_paragraph: With three weeks left before Election Day, former President Donald J. Trump is pushing to the forefront of his campaign a menacing political threat: that he would use the power of the presidency to crush those who disagree with him.
articles.byline: By Lisa Lerer and Michael Gold

articles.headline: Can Remote Workers Reverse Brain Drain?
articles.snippet: Researchers found that when remote workers were paid to move to Tulsa, Okla., everyone came out ahead.
articles.abstract: Researchers found that when remote workers were paid to move to Tulsa, Okla., everyone came out ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: Business leaders and local officials in Tulsa, Okla., puzzled for years over how to fill the hole created when young people left for big coastal cities. What, they wondered, could keep professionals rooted in the heartland?

articles.headline: Small-Town Pennsylvania Is Changing, and Democrats See Opportunity
articles.snippet: Lancaster County, famous for its Amish communities, regularly votes Republican. But the demographics are shifting here and throughout the state.
articles.abstract: Lancaster County, famous for its Amish communities, regularly votes Republican. But the demographics are shifting here and throughout the state.
articles.lead_paragraph: Politics came last at the 89th Ephrata Fair Parade.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson, Robert Gebeloff and Rachel Wisniewski For The New York Times

articles.headline: Where a Million Desperate People Are Finding Shelter in Lebanon
articles.snippet: Schools, clubs and parks have become places of refuge as the displaced seek safety amid Israeli bombings.
articles.abstract: Schools, clubs and parks have become places of refuge as the displaced seek safety amid Israeli bombings.
articles.lead_paragraph: At dusk, the parking lot of Tripoli’s Quality Inn is packed with cars and families milling about. Children’s shouts fill the air, reminding some of better times, when the hotel hosted weddings and birthday parties.
articles.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin and David Guttenfelder
